history.content:
There is little overlap between Math 113 and Math 110; the only overlap I can remember were the vector spaces in relation to fields, which is covered in the very end of 113, but I think that the material from 54 is enough to understand that part of the course. That being said, Math 113 is an upper division class (and a hard one), so it does require some sort of mathematical maturity (e.g. being able to write rigorous proofs), so Math 110 could help you with that; however, if you are confident in your math skills, I don't think that taking 110 is in any way necessary.

-----

I imagine 113 can vary a lot depending on who teaches it, but here are my thoughts based on my experience:

110 shouldn't be necessary. CS70 should have given you enough of that type of mathematical maturity. What might be a concern is that you said you took "up to Math 54 in high school". If the rigor of your high school math classes wasn't comparable to Berkeley, or it was so long ago that you've forgotten a lot, you might struggle a bit with certain things. In my case, the only "math" class I had taken at Berkeley was CS70, and all the math classes I had taken elsewhere were a joke. I still managed to do well in 113, but I had to get a lot of help to make up for my weak math background. Often it wasn't that the material required it, exactly, but that the homework problems were written under the assumption that I had learned and remembered everything from 1a, 1b, and 54. But if your background isn't an issue, or you're willing to put in a bit more work than someone who took those classes at Berkeley, you should be perfectly fine.

There is little overlap between Math 113 and Math 110; the only overlap I can remember were the vector spaces in relation to fields, which is covered in the very end of 113, but I think that the material from 54 is enough to understand that part of the course. That being said, Math 113 is an upper division class (and a hard one), so it does require some sort of mathematical maturity (e.g. being able to write rigorous proofs), so Math 110 could help you with that; however, if you are confident in your math skills, I don't think that taking 110 is in any way necessary.

children.subject: Just as a reference, I took Math 110 and 113 together and I would say having knowledge of 110 helped in 113 and vice versa but only in terms of seeing and understanding the subtlety behind certain concepts. I think people often recommend taking Math 110 before 113 because it helps ease the transition into upper division math better than 113 because the topics in 110 are familiar enough (from 54).  I think CS70 is enough in terms of mathematical maturity but there is not as much emphasis on proof writing compared to a math class. However, if you are comfortable enough sitting in lecture where they literally spend the entire class proving one theorem, and are comfortable writing your own rigorous proofs, then I would definitely say go ahead and take 113.

history.content:
Hi, I'm looking to take an upper div math course next semester and 113 interests me a lot. However, I've heard that taking 113 without 110 isn't recommended. In terms of my background, I took up to Math 54 in highschool and am currently taking CS 70, so this would also be my first class at Berkeley within the Math department.

For other CS majors who have taken CS70, would the level of mathematical maturity developed throughout the class be enough to prepare me for 113 or should I just take 110 first? Thanks
history.subject: Math 113 with only CS70
